prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking if the author of the story is in the wrong for telling her friend that her being single is because she has five kids by different fathers. The main points here are the interactions between the two friends, the insults the author received, and her response.

First, the friend has a history of making comments that the author finds insulting. The friend's remarks about the author's weight, job, and dating life seem to be personal and dismissive. The author tried to brush them off, but eventually, when the friend kept badgering her, she responded with the truth about the friend's situation. 

The key issue here is whether the author's response was appropriate. The friend was asking for advice but in a way that was condescending. The author pointed out the friend's situation as a possible reason for her difficulties. However, the friend reacted negatively, leading to the fallout.

Now, the mutual friends are criticizing the author, saying she has "skinny privilege" and is being entitled. The author argues that she worked hard and isn't privileged. But the question is about whether she was in the wrong. 

From a social standpoint, even if the author's statement was true, delivering it in a direct and blunt manner during a tense conversation might have been unkind. Friends are supposed to support each other, and while the author was justified in feeling insulted, her response might have crossed a line by being critical of her friend's personal life. 

The friend's behavior was also problematic, but the author's response, though honest, could have been more compassionate. There might have been a better way to address the situation without attacking the friend's choices. So, considering all that, the author might be in the wrong for how she handled the situation, even if her intentions were to be truthful.
